p: The water activity ( a w) affects the reactivity as well. At a low water concentration/ a w, the reactants are more concentrated [ 50]. However, if the system is so concentrated that diffusion is impeded, the reaction rate decreases, as in the case of powders, and in the glassy state (minimum a w ~ 0.4) [ 50, 52, 85]. Diffusion and molecular mobility can be increased by increasing the a w. This, in turn, generally increases the rate and extent of the glycation reaction. The highest reaction velocity is achieved at water activities of 0.5â€“0.8 [ 45]. Furthermore, the activation energy of the reaction is lowered by a higher water content [ 44]. However, a very high water concentration/ a w slows down the Maillard reaction due to dilution of the reactants [ 89].
